metadata.title: Selective Mutism
description: According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition  (DSM-5 ), children with selective mutism (SM) do not initiate speech or respond when spoken to by other persons.(1) Diagnostic criteria for SM are as follows:
Consistent failure to speak in specific social situations in which speaking is expected despite being able to speak in other situations(1)
Failure to speak interferes with social communication or educational or occupational achievement(1)
Disturbance has lasted at least 1 month (not only the first month of school)(1)
Failure to speak is not caused by a lack of knowledge or inability to use spoken language to communicate(1)
The disturbance cannot be accounted for by another communication disorder (e.g., childhood-onset  fluency disorder)(1)

ICD-9 codes.309.83: adjustment reaction with withdrawal; elective mutism as adjustment reaction

presentation signs and symptoms: Patient fails to speak in specific social situations despite speaking in other situations.(1)Individuals with SM are most often children or adolescents whose failure to speak interferes with their social interaction as well as with their educational or vocational achievement.(2) “Selective” refers to the inability to speak in select environmental conditions or with select individuals.(2) SM is a rare disorder with incidence estimates ranging from 18 in 10,000 to 16 in 2,256.(2) Anxiety disorders and developmental disorders of speech and language often co-occur  with SM.(2) Associated features of SM include social anxiety such as excessive shyness, fear of social embarrassment, social isolation, withdrawal, and excessive clinging to parent.(1) Other associated traits include compulsivity, oppositional behavior (particularly at home), temper tantrums, and negativism.(1) Extreme cases of SM in adults are rare, but persons who have had SM as children often exhibit symptoms of social anxiety into adulthood(3) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: It is important to obtain information about the child’s history from multiple sources (e.g., parents, caregivers, teachers, grandparents) and to consider the child’s behavior in different environments.(2) When assessing the child for the first time, do not place demands on verbal communication if the child is resistant. Do not force the child to speak; instead, begin with comprehension tasks that require simple pointing or nodding responses and reinforce all communication attempts.(33) The first few sessions should focus on allowing the child to become familiar and comfortable with the therapist(33)

pathogenesis: Results of large-scale  studies have found that SM often coexists with anxiety disorders and that high rates of shyness,social phobia, and social avoidance have been found in children with SM.(3) Children exhibit shyness and social anxiety inthe school or community setting prior to the onset of SM(3)

In a study conducted in the United States with 35 children (ages 5–12 years) with SM (n = 10), social phobia (n = 11), or nodiagnosis (n = 14), researchers found that psychophysiological measures (e.g., systolic blood pressure, heart rate) indicatedthat the children in the SM group experienced less arousal during social interactions than did the other groups of childrenin the study. For this reason, the authors of the study hypothesized that failure to speak in SM might be an avoidancemechanism (a means of preventing anxiety/overstimulation from social situations), which would account for the observedlack of arousal in this group(32)
risk factors: Family or patient history of communication disorders, anxiety disorders, or depression(2,8)
Speaking a minority language as a native language; a school environment that does not support a child learning a secondlanguage(4)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When was the patient’s SM first noticed? Was there a traumatic event immediately preceding symptoms of SM?

course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications have been prescribed; are they being taken? For example, note if the child is taking any medications for anxiety
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed : Report any diagnostic (e.g., psychological, speech-language, hearing) tests that have been previously completed
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., yoga) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and if they are helpful
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether child has had previous psychological or speech-language  therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were effective

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Obtain a description of the child’s communication in each environment (e.g., school, community, home) and with all regular communication partners -In which environments and with which persons does the child communicate the most? The least?Document psychosocial status (including shyness or social phobia) as well as family history of psychiatric disorders, as SM commonly coexists with psychosocial issues -Behavioral inhibition (a condition that appears as early as infancy in which children respond to novel stimuli with very strong reactions) has been theorized to be a precursor to SM. Infants who exhibit behavioral inhibition, especially in social situations, have an increased risk for SM(35) -Note any signs of anxiety in the clinical setting and gain information from parent and teacher report on any excessive anxiety or panic and when they occur(2) -SM can be conceptualized as a specific phobia for expressive speech and has been successfully treated with cognitive behavioral therapy(9) -In a study conducted with clients from a pediatric anxiety clinic in the United States, researchers found that children with SM had greater social problems than the children with mixed anxiety or mixed anxiety/attention-deficit/hyperactivity  disorder (ADHD)(31) -Review reports from psychiatric professionals, if available  -A psychologist or psychiatrist may administer a questionnaire to screen for anxiety, such as the Screen for Child Anxiety-Related  Emotional Disorders (SCARED)(10)Note hearing abilities -Does the patient have known hearing loss? -If so, does the patient use hearing aids? Cochlear implants? -Document any history of hearing problems or ear infections(2) -In a study conducted in Israel with 62 children (31 of whom had a diagnosis of SM), researchers found that 59% of the children with SM exhibited absent middle-ear  acoustic reflex (MEAR) and/or abnormal MEAR decay, which was significantly higher than the control group (10%). The MEAR is activated during vocalization in humans and is theorized to help decrease the masking influence of the speaker’s own voice so he or she can hear other sounds while vocalizing. Another reflex involved in monitoring self-vocalization  is the medial olivocochlear bundle (MOCB) reflex; researchers found that reduced MOCB function was present in 38% of children with SM, which was significantly higher than in the control group(8%)(28) -A hearing screen might be difficult to achieve for a patient with SM due to the selective nature of the responses; however, if the patient appears to have difficulty hearing as evidenced by requests for repetition, leaning in to hear, or complete unawareness of sounds/speech, recommendation for a full audiological workup is appropriate Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document any child or family history of psychiatric or learning disorders.(2) Document the onset of SM
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Document relevant developmental issues, including prenatal/perinatal problems, difficulties with motor, speech, or language development, or odd social behavior
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask child or caregivers about other symptoms the patient is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: What type of school does the child attend? Is the language of the child’s school the same as the child’s home language? How big is the class? Does the child participate in extracurricular activities? Obtain parent and teacher report on the child’s interactions with peers and friendships
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the child use any assistive or alternative methods of communication (AAC)?
social and occupational history.living environment: With whom does child live (e.g., caregivers, siblings)? -What language(s) is/are spoken and heard at home? If more than one, document amount of time each language is spoken and/or heard by the patient

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Tests for language and articulation will need to be adapted to the child’s level of verbal ability and willingness –Selective Mutism Questionnaire (SMQ)(5) -19-item  questionnaire to be completed by the parents regarding speaking behavior at school, with the family, and in social situations outside of school –Speech Situations Questionnaire (SSQ)(12) -Parent and teacher versions available -Can assist with identification of specific environments or communicative partners with whom patient does not speak
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Speech and language examination (including reading)Describe child’s nonverbal interactions through observation (e.g., classroom and clinic) and parent/teacher reportArticulation is often best screened through parent report in cases of SM. If there are concerns, administer a standardized articulation test, if possible, or have the parent administer a simple articulation test at home while audio taping the responses -For detailed information on articulation and phonological disorders in children, see the series of Clinical Reviews on speech sound disorders Receptive language tests that require pointing (e.g., Peabody Picture V ocabulary Test-4)might  be easier to administer before expressive language tasks.(11,12) During initial test administration, it is important to put the child at ease and not pressure the child to talk(2) -In a study conducted in Canada comparing the scores on receptive language and academic ability standardized tests obtained from both children with SM and age-matched  peers without SM, researchers found that girls with SM had lower receptive language skills than their age-matched, typically developing peers (no difference found for boys with SM)(12)It might be necessary to train parents to administer some expressive language tasks at home and audiotape or videotape the child’s responses. Parents can also be trained to administer simple narrative tasks (e.g., story-retelling)  using wordless picture books.(2) Some older children who are resistant to using oral language may provide written responses to expressive language subtests. For example, the Formulated Sentences subtest of the Clinical Evaluation of Language Fundamentals–fifth edition (CELF-5)  can be administered as a written sentence formulation task.(13) The Word Classes subtest of the CELF-5  can be printed so that the child can indicate semantically related choices on the paper rather than orally.(2) Combine standardized testing results with language samples gathered during play, at school, and at home(2)Refer to parent and teacher report for information on language pragmatics. Examples of questions -Does the child initiate conversation with any peers at school/home? -Does the child initiate interactions nonverbally? -Does the child use turn-taking  skills? -Does the child have appropriate eye contact? -Does the child respond to questions verbally or nonverbally? -How does the child request and get needs met (e.g., food) at school/home?If possible, assess vocal function, including vocal quality, loudness, pitch, and endurance; if there are specific concerns regarding voice, refer to otolaryngologist for complete workup to rule out laryngeal pathologies prior to completing a full evaluationAnT709181If possible, rule out or identify atypical speech dysfluencies (stuttering) -For detailed information on disorders of fluency see the series of the Clinical Reviews on this topicTo assess emergent literacy skills, use nonverbal tasks that require manipulatives (e.g., Lindamood Auditory Conceptualization Test) or request that the child hold up fingers to indicate number of sounds in a syllable or word.(2,14) To test reading comprehension, use written questions or yes/no questions after the child reads silently. Rely on teacher report to select appropriate level text. Document grades for reading and obtain any writing samples
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: If articulation concerns are noted, an oral mechanism exam should be performed only if child is willing. Begin with items that are less invasive (e.g., “pucker lips,” “place tongue tip on upper lip”) and proceed only if child is compliantAsk parent about child’s self-care  skills at home. If warranted, perform a standardized interview of child’s daily living skills (e.g., Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales)(15)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem solving) –Obtain report from teacher(s) on the child’s functioning at school and academic ability, including literacy, math, and attention skills

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Given the complications of assessment, initial therapy sessions might be diagnostic. It is important to put the child at ease in the initial sessions rather than focus on obtaining complete information about the patient’s communication abilities

It is important to identify and eliminate any behaviors that may be reinforcing the SM. For example, if a teacher asks the child a question, receives no response, and then withdraws the request, the child’s behavior will be negatively reinforced(6)
Effective treatment involves consistent response among all adults who interact with the child(16)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Treatment is warranted if SM interferes with language development and/or social, educational, or vocational development and activities. The DSM-5  specifies that the mutism must last at least 1 month in order to meet diagnostic criteria.(1) SM might only occur in one environment (e.g., school), so it is essential that collaboration occur regularly between the adults who are involved in the care and education of the child
assessment plan of care.rule out: SM should be distinguished from a language disorder, articulation disorder, apraxia, fluency (stuttering) disorder, behavioral disorder (e.g., defiance), deficits in pragmatic language (e.g., autism spectrum disorder [ASD]), and hearing loss. Rule out nonnative proficiency in language. It is recommended that SM not be diagnosed in a bilingual child unless the mutism lasts for at least 6 months.(8) If the mutism occurs only as a symptom of a psychotic disorder or developmental disorder, SM should be ruled out(4)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Given the multifaceted nature of this disorder, there is need for family and school cooperation and referral to a psychiatrist or psychologist to assist in treating anxiety.(17) The team approach, especially within the school environment, has been proven effective for SM.(18) The treatment team usually consists at minimum of the child, the parents, the teacher, the psychotherapist, and the speech-language  pathologist (SLP).(16,17,18) Additional team members might include the school principal, special education teacher, school nurse, and guidance counselor.(18) Speech therapy alone is unlikely to be successful as a form of intervention.(4) Clinical trials have indicated that medications to reduce anxiety (e.g., selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors [SSRIs]) are effective in treating anxiety symptoms, but that behavioral intervention is still needed with children with persistent SM.(2,19) When family therapy, psychodynamic, or medical interventions are warranted, refer to a psychologist or psychiatrist as appropriate(4)
treatment summary: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is often used based upon the view that SM is a learned behavior that develops as an escape from anxiety or as a way of gaining attention from others.(4) The most common behavioral treatments are contingency management and shaping, stimulus fading, positive reinforcement, systematic desensitization, social skills training, and modeling(4) –Authors of literature reviews of CBT studies have concluded that 1) some treatment is better than no treatment and 2) there is much evidence to support the use of behavioral interventions for SM(4,20)

Cognitive behavioral treatment –Contingency management and shaping -Techniques of contingency management and shaping techniques might involve a reinforcement menu that is developed in collaboration with the child. Reinforcement is then provided for approximations of verbal behaviors (e.g., head nodding, mouthing, whispering, pointing) with the eventual goal of speech(4) -Case studies have indicated that contingency management programs are useful in increasing verbalizations, but effects on generalized speech are unclear(4)  -In a single-participant  alternating treatment design study conducted in the United States in which treatment A was child-focused,  exposure-based practice and treatment B was parent-focused contingency management, 9 children were treated for SM(21) -Treatment A involved shaping, modeling, prompting, and in vivo exposure with an established hierarchy of specific situations(21) -Shaping involved humming, vocalizing with the mouth open, mouthing words, whispering words, whispering sentences, and whispering sentences with increasing volume until spontaneous communication was accomplished -Additionally, anxiety-reduction  techniques such as breathing retraining were utilized -Treatment B focused on the parents; parents were taught to reward their children for appropriate speech in public places and punish them for failure to speak in these situations (including loss of toys or TV time)(21) -Therapists established routines for the public situations to increase the opportunities for the child to speak -Teachers were asked to participate in the reward/punishment procedures as well -Positive end-state  situations were achieved for 8 of the 9 participants; based on the data obtained from the study, researchers concluded that both treatment approaches may be effective for increasing audible speech in children with SM; however, treatment A appeared significantly more effective(21) –Stimulus fading -Stimulus fading can be used in conjunction with contingency management and refers to the technique of gradually introducing more persons and places in which speech is rewarded(4) -Stimulus fading interventions have been successful in increasing verbalizations and the variety of communicative contexts in which the child is successful(4) -In a pilot study conducted in Norway, 7 children with SM, ages 3 to 5 years, were treated with a multimodal approach using defocused communication and stimulus fading/sliding-in  technique. The treatment program was initiated in the home and transitioned into kindergarten for a maximum of 6 months. In sessions with the children, therapists used defocused communication techniques which included sitting next to the child rather than across, “thinking aloud” rather than asking direct questions, and giving increased response time for the child rather than answering for the child. After an average of 14 weeks of treatment, 6/7 children spoke in kindergarten settings, which was the goal of the program(34) –Systematic desensitization -Systematic desensitization involves the use of relaxation techniques (e.g., progressive muscle relaxation, imagery exercises) with exposure to successively more anxiety-provoking situations(4) -This technique appears to work better with older versus younger children(4) –Self-modeling -Self-modeling  involves recording or videotaping the child speaking and editing the tapes to depict the child speaking in situations in which he or she has previously remained mute(4) -In single-subject  studies using self-modeling, children have shown improvement immediately after intervention and at follow-up.  However, this technique has been used in conjunction with other behavioral techniques (e.g., positive reinforcement and stimulus fading), and it is difficult to determine the exact effects of self-modeling(4) -Caution: some children are resistant to hearing their voices recorded and taping will actually increase anxiety about speaking(4) –Behavioral language training intervention -This treatment is focused on using behavioral principles to train the child in nonverbal attending, verbal imitation, and functional conversation -In a randomized controlled pilot study conducted in the United States with 21 children with SM ages 4 to 8, researchers found that those children randomized to a 24-week  Integrated Behavior Therapy for Selective Mutism (IBTSM) showed significantly increased functional speaking behavior posttreatment compared to the waitlist control group. 75% of the children in the experimental group met the response criteria immediately following the program. Additionally, the children in the IBTSM group demonstrated significant improvements in the number of words spoken at school compared to baseline and were reported to have significant reductions in social anxiety per parent report (but not per teacher report). Researchers found that these clinical gains were maintained at a3-month follow-up.  The IBTSM program involved a hierarchy of speaking tasks in which positive reinforcement was provided for completing each task. Home assignments such as speaking to a familiar conversational partner in an empty classroom or having a play date with a  classmate in which no talking was expected were also part of the program, and by the end of the intervention the parents were trained to carryout maintenance activities to prevent relapse(27) -In a single-subject  study conducted in the United States, researchers examined the effects of behavioral language training on verbal responses of a child (age 7) with intellectual delay and SM; results indicated an increase in spontaneous verbalizations in both the home and school setting(22) –Social problem-solving  intervention -This intervention involves teaching the child a set of rules to increase child’s ability to 1) identify salient social stimuli; 2) identify the most appropriate social behaviors for the situation; 3) perform the target social behavior; and 4) evaluate the behavior once it is performed(23) -In a multiple baseline study conducted in the United States, two sisters with SM (ages 5 and 7) were given social problem-solving  training sessions 2 times/week in 30-minutes  sessions to increase their ability to answer questions in class(23) -During the sessions, they practiced answering 5 questions that would later be given to them by the teacher in class -During the sessions, the therapist provided a rationale for speaking audibly, reviewed the questions, and gave verbal praise and error correction -At baseline, both subjects answered 0 questions correctly in the classroom; during intervention and in follow-up sessions, they answered all questions correctly in the classroom. However, teachers noted little generalization to interactions with peers outside of the classroom –In a case series with 5 children ages 6 to 11 conducted in Singapore, researchers described a web-based  cognitive behavioral therapy program to treat SM. Researchers modified a Canadian web-based  cognitive behavioral program to be culturally appropriate for the Singaporean children. The program was 14 weeks long with 8 training sessions and 6 practice sessions; parents were given a log-in  and encouraged to practice at home as well. Posttreatment, 4/5 children included in the case series demonstrated improvements in the frequency of speech during therapy sessions at home, in school, and in other social situations(30)

Communication-based  interventions –A child with a co-occurring  speech and/or language disorder might benefit from treatment of speech or language deficits if he or she is willing to attend sessions outside of the classroom. Addressing speech-language  goals in a less-threatening situation might facilitate eventual communication in the classroom. In addition, the focus on specific targets (e.g., syntactic or literacy concepts) may take attention away from the mutism and possibly facilitate progress(2) –Social/communication-based  intervention -This systematic approach can be used to increase social interactions between the child and peers. Peer interactions can be first encouraged in low-anxiety,  nonverbal interactions that are monitored by parents or teachers. As the child becomes comfortable with these interactions, the verbal demands can be slightly increased. This intervention approach follows principles that are recommended but have not empirically tested by researchers(2)

Other types of treatments showing some evidence of effectiveness are family therapy interventions and multimodal interventions(8,24) –Music therapy has been described in a descriptive case study, but there are no experimental studies investigating its effectiveness(25) –Authors of another case study describe drama therapy with behavioral interventions as a successful treatment in a 5-year-old  girl with SM(26) -In this case study, the child’s speech increased not only in the therapy room but also generalized to non-therapy  settings with both family members and friends(26) –Authors of a case study with a 10-year-old  boy with SM described use of an expressive therapies continuum to treat the child. Initially, sessions began with structured play activities to ensure the child was comfortable with the activities and with the therapist. As the sessions progressed, the therapist introduced play, drama, and art-based  activities (on the expressive therapies continuum) to increase the child’s confidence with self-expression  and reduce anxiety in social situations(29)

Home programs are rarely described in the research because of the preliminary nature of the research in clinical settings and the absence of signs of the disorder at home . reduced anxiety in speaking situations: Systematic observations, parent/teacher report, anxiety measures, standardized behavior rating scales(20)
increased verbalizations in a variety of: Systematic observations, parent/teacher report, standardized behavior rating scales, academic measures (curriculum-basedand or standardized), and/or standardized language measures(20)

maintenance or prevention: After treatment, follow-up  session/s and observations should be performed to determine if the effects of therapy have been maintained
patient education: Parent or caregivers should be educated about possible causes of the disorder and the potential effects on social and academic development
